editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The Duke's mistress, as it was presented by her majesty's servants, at the private house in drury-lane.
London, printed by John Norton, for Andrew Crooke and William Cooke. 1638. 6

lg.l: So various are the palates of our age
That nothing is presented on the stage,
Though ne'er so square, and apted to the laws
Of poesy, that can win full applause,
This likes a story, that a cunning plot
This wit, that lines, here one, he knows not what.
But after all this looking several ways,
We do observe the general guests to plays,
Meet in opinion of two strains: that please
Satire, and wantonness, the last of these
Though old, if in new dressing it appear
Will move a smile from all, but shall not hear.
Our author hath no guilt of scurrile friends.
For satire they do know best what it means,
That dare apply, and if a poet's pen,
Aiming at general errors not the men,
'Tis not his fault, the safest cure is, they
That purge their bosoms, may see any play.
But here we quit your fear of satire too,
And with these disadvantages to you
Thus humbly bow, to such helps ta'en away
What hope is there many will like the play,
But good or bad, have patience but two hours,
The poet's credit is at stake with ours.

div.head: Actus primus.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: We are like to have a brave, and jolly time on't.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: The court looks now as't should be, after such
A tempest, what should follow but a calm,
And sunbeams? where's the Duchess?
And yet as the case stands, we can scarce give her
That title, all her glory is eclipsed,
She's i'th West, poor gentlewoman I can
But pity her, I mean Euphemia.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I dare not speak.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou mayst speak any thing
That's courtly, and in fashion.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: But the Duke.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Is Duke, and heaven preserve him, let him have
His humour, and his mistresses, what are we
The worse, nay let's consider like wise-men
We are the better for't, it gives us liberty,
And matter for our dutiful imitation.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: But she was his Duchess.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: A lady of,
A flowing sweetness, and but in his eyes
Can want no beauty, how her nature may
Thus cruelly affronted, keep that soft,
And noble temper.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Take heed, and be wise,
We are or should be courtiers, if it please
The Duke for reasons best known to himself
To have more wives, I say 'tis fit he have 'em,
I make it my own ease.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Thou art not married.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, I dare not for that reason, cause I hold it
Unfit my conscience should be limited,
But we are private men, and though the laws
Have power on us, the state, and dukedom may
Suffer, if he that is the soul of all,
I mean the Duke, should waste his life with one,
One melancholy wife, come let me tell thee
Since he has chosen one, that he thinks fairer
'Tis happy for his first to keep her head on,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Couldst thou have thought so cruel, 'las Euphemia

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No thou art deceived, if I were Duke
'Tis ten to one I'd have no wife at all,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not of mine own, while any of my subjects
Had those I could affect; whom I would have
Presented by their husbands, they should do
Themselves that courtesy, none would deny,
Considering what may follow.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Besides horns.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Right, if the toy be gamesome, the husbands made
For ever.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And his wife a great one,
Horn's excuse for all.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The old mind still.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know my constitution
His countenance wears some sore of discontent
Does he not appear cloudy.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Let's speak to him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My lord, — my lord.
Not answer.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: He does not hear.
My noblest lord.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If I did think he were proud now of a sudden,
I would not ask him how he does, to save
His life — I'll speak once more, my worthiest lord,
Leontio.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I ha' wakened him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Valerio, and Silvio.
I am your servants.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not that we grudge our duties to your lordship
Or breath, for without flattery, I dare
Be hoarse with praising, and with praying for you,
But we would willingly have your lordship take
Notice, when we express our hearts to serve you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your pardon gentlemen, I am confident
You have more virtue than to let me suffer in your opinions

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You look sad.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And talk as you had but started from a dream,
I dare not be too bold to inquire the cause,
But your face will teach others melancholy.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Now in this general mirth it must appear,
The greater wonder to behold your trouble.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I shall betray myself, keep in my passions.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: There's something in't more than we apprehend.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What should distract the freedom of your sole
Kinsman, and only favourite to the Duke,
The people's love too, and these seldom meet,
The minion of the soldiers, who honour you
Most infinitely for your valour, and your bounty.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Flatter not gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll be your hind first.
Eclipse not, sir, the glories of your mind
With this strange melancholy, I would not for
My hopes the Duke should see this dulness, he
May with unhappy jealousy interpret —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What jealousy?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is my heart transparent?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now joy revels in the court,
By his command, and his example too;
Do not affront his pleasure, I am bold,
But 'tis my zeal, that would not have you suffer,
And you may give it pardon.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I must thank
Thy love Valerio, thy heart does speak
A noble friendship, you shall witness gentlemen
I will be very pleasant, keep, keep in
Ye rebel thoughts, and take some other time
To show your wildness.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Observed you that?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Shall I be bold to ask your lordship a question?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: You will pardon the folly on't?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What is't? be clear with me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Are you not in love, my lord?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: In love?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have shrewd conjectures.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: From what?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: From these dull symptoms, if you be

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Let me be your physician, 'tis a woman
I must presume.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What does a man love else?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: There be those men are in love with their own clothes
Their wits, their follies, their estates, themselves,
But if you love a woman, let me advise you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Hear him my lord, his practice upon that sex
Has made him learned.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Something I have observed
After a hundred mistresses, I had been dull else,
But to the point.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How would you advise me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I would not counsel you not to love at all,
As some that are all satyr, 'gainst the sex,
love me a handsome lady, but so love her
That still your heart find room for a fresh beauty,
For twenty, for a thousand.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is inconstancy
So easy, and so pardonable.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Why d'ye shift
Your shirt, the linen's fine, but not so clean
And sweet after a journey, 'tis a justice
To change: and a security a woman
Is tyrant, when she finds a dotage, love
But wisely, to delight our hearts, not ruin 'em
With too severe impression.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Prithee tell me,
What do most men desire that are in love?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In this wise love I mean? why, my lord, they
Desire to enjoy their mistresses, what else
Can be expected? and 'tis necessary
In my opinion.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hadst thou been woman,
Thou wod'st not have been so cruel.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Troth, my lord,
I know not how the sex might have corrupted me
But had I been Adonis, without question
My lady Venus should have had no cause
To accuse my bashfulness, I should have left
The forest to have hunted —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I believe it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But I must be content.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Nothing will much trouble thy head Valerio.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I do not vex myself with much inquiry
What men do in the Indies, or what trade
The great turk's on, nor what his design is,
Nor does the state at home much trouble me,
After the wars I enjoy my limbs, and can
Boast some activity, until some woman
In kindness take me down, be ruled by me,
Employ your spring and youth upon those joys
They are fit for, beget a new Elysium,
Under some pleasing shade let's lie and laugh
our temples crowned with roses, with the choice,
And richest blood of grapes, quicken our veins,
Some fair cheeked boys skinking our swelling cups,
And we with jovial souls shooting them round
At each man's lip a mistress.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I did look for this before.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They in this bower
Shall with their songs, and music charm our ears,
And nimbly dance, their bright hair loosely spread;
Nor shall they more their amorous beauties hide
Then those contended for the golden ball.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou wod'st imagine many fine devices
But after all these pleasures, as there is
A limit, and a period set, what will
Succeed these raptures, when they are passed enjoyings
But leave so many stings upon our thoughts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We won't think of that, or if we do,
We'll venture upon fortune's courtesy.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou art resolute Valerio, if ere sorrow
Lay siege to me, I'll wish thee my companion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am your humble creature, and shall be honoured
In your commands.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: My lord, the Duke
Asked for you.
sp.stage: Ascanio whispers with Valerio, and Silvio. Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I'll attend. Whither in haste?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We are commanded to attend

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: It is his pleasure, we should wait upon her
To his presence.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ardelia,
It will become you, and but that his highness
Exacts my person, I should be a part
Of her attendance, but not serve her with
Half the devotion, I would pay Euphemia
The too much injured Duchess, now a stranger
To the Duke's bosom, while another sits,
And rules his heart, but this prepares my happiness,
My hopes grow from her misery, which may
Incline Euphemia to pity me.
I must use art.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Good madam have more comfort.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is not that she? her habit like her fortune
Most black, and ominous, here's a change of state,
No noise of waiters, and officious troops,
Of courtiers futter here, where are the train
Of ladies, with more blossom than the spring,
Ambitious to present their duties to her,
Where be those jewels, whose proud blaze did use
To vie with sunbeams, and strike gazers blind?
All gone behind a cloud? how she observes
The structures, which more soft than Dionisio
Seem to incline their marble heads, and sweat
In the compassion of her injury,
My heart is labouring for breath, and yet
I dare not speak to her, the Duke has spies
Upon her; and his anger carries ruin.

div.stage: Enter courtiers, who pass by neglectfully.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Sure I should know this place.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: 'Tis the court madam.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: And those were courtiers that passed by?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: They were.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Some of them served me once, but now the Duke
Has discharged all, why dost not thou forsake me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I served you madam, for yourself, and cannot
Think on you with less reverence, for your change:
Of fortune.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Is not that Leontio?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: It is madam.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Does he decline me too? though I am miserable,
My grief would not infect him, but he must
Compose himself to please, the Duke, whose creature
He has been always.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will speak to her,
Though death in the Duke's eye threatens to kill me,
Great mistress.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: You do not well Leontio to insult
Upon my misery, Dionisio's frown
may make your field as barren.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By all virtue,
And by yourself the mistress, I have not
One thought so irreligious in my soul
I weep for your misfortune, and shall study
All humble ways to serve you.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: You have been noble.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your titles are all sacred still with me,
The Duke's neglect cannot unprince you here;
O let not hasty sorrow boast a triumph
Over so great a mind, let not that beauty
Wither with apprehension of your wrong
That may be soon repented, and the storm
That cowardly would shake that comeliest building
Make for your happiness, some lament your fate.
Whose looks speak mirth, be confident, the Duke
Will chide the unlawful flame, that like rude
And wand'ring meteor, led him from your virtues
With so much danger to embrace Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: The Duke shall know your compliments.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: No more, lest for your charity to me,
For I must call it so, you ruin not
Your favour with the Duke, farewell Leontio
Yet I would pray one favour from you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Me?
My life's your servant.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: If you hear the Duke
Speak of me, as I fear he never will
But in displeasure, tell him I will think it
No cruelty to take this poor life from me,
Rather than let me draw a wretched breath
With general scorn, let him command me dead,
And I forgive him, otherwise farewell.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That close showed something, like a will to be,
Revenged her breast heaved up, and fell again,
While both her eyes shot a contention upward,
As they would seem to put just heaven in mind
How much she suffers.
If grief thus become her,
What magic will not love put on? I must
Stifle my passion. Pallante, welcome,
You are well met in court;
Where dost thou live Pallante?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Everywhere ,
Yet nowhere to any purpose, we are out
Of use, and like our engines are laid by
To gather dust, the court I ha' not skill in,
I want the trick of flattery, my lord,
I cannot bow to scarlet, and goldlace,
Embroidery is not an idol for my worship,
Give me the wars again.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But yet remember we fight for peace,
The end of war.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: I never did, my lord.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Fight for peace, I fought for pay, and honour,
Peace will undo us.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis the corruption of our peace, that men
Glorious in spirit, and desert, are not
Encouraged.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: The faults somewhere.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I presume
Thou art not of so tyrannous a nature,
But thou couldst be content to wear rich clothes,
Feed high, and want no fortune without venturing
To buy them at the price of blood.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: I could.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And I'll engage thou shalt, be this the prologue.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Not I, keep, keep your money.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You do not scorn my bounty.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: You may guess
That fortune has not doted much upon me,
And yet I must refuse it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your reason pray?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Why ten to one I shall spend it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: So 'tis meant.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: 'Twill make me gay a while, but I shall pawn
My robes, and put on these again,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou shalt not
While I have fortune to preserve thee otherwise,

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: I say out of my love to you I must not,
I never yet took money upon charity,
I earned it in the war, and I'll deserve't
In peace, of you I cannot, 'tis my misery
To be unserviceable.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is that your scruple?
But that I know thy humour, I should think
This cunning, but you shall not, sir, despair,
I shall find ways to have mentioned
In your accounts for merits, doubt not, I
Will give you occasion to deserve more.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: On those conditions I'll take more, and think the better
Of my own life, honoured by your employments.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The Duke.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ha? Leontio.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: If I have any brains, he showed a passion
Did not become him to your Duchess sir

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Presumes he on his blood, above our favour?
Dares he but in a thought control our pleasure,
No more, we'll take no knowledge, o my lord
You absent yourself too much, though we confess
Our state must owe much to your care, we would not
Your offices should waste you with employments
Preserve your health I pray —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I never did
Enjoy it more than when I studied service,
And duties to your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Music, the minutes
Are sad i'th absence of Ardelia,
And move too slow, quicken their pace with lutes,
And voices.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more; we will be music of ourselves,
And spare your arts, thought of Ardelia,
should strike a harmony through every heart,
What brow looks sad, when we command delight?
We shall account that man a traitor to us,
That wears one sullen cloud upon his face,
I'll read his soul in't, and by our bright mistress,
Than which the world contains no richer beauty,
Punish his daring sin.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He will deserve it
Great sir, that shall offend with the least sadness,
Or were it so possessed, yet your command
That stretches to the soul, would make it smile,
And force a bravery, severe old age
Shall lay aside his sullen gravity,
And revel like a youth, the froward matrons
For this day, shall repent their years, and coldness
Of blood, and wish again their tempting beauties
To dance like wanton lovers.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My Leontio,
In this then thou dost present our bosom to thee,
What's he?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A gentleman that has deserved
For service in your late wars, sir, a captain.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He may turn courtier now, we have no use
Of noise, we can march here without a drum,
I hope we are not in arrears to him,
He haunts us for no pay?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your bounty beside that, hath won their hearts.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why has he no better clothes? this is a day
Of triumph.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: I beseech your highness' pardon,
I ha' drunk your health in better clothes, despise
My Christian buff; this is the fruits of peace,
I'll wait on you again.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Where's my Ardelia?
How at the name my spirits leap within me,
And the amorous winds do catch it from my lips
To sweeten the air — heaven at the sound
Looks clear, and lovely, and the earth put's on
A spring to welcome it, speak Leontio
Strozzi, gentlemen, but she appears.
For whom the world shall wear eternal shiue,
Brightest Ardelia, Queen of love, and me,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The only honour, my ambition climbs too,
Is to be held your highness' humblest handmaid.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Call me thy servant, what
New charms her looks does throw upon my soul.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: How the Duke gazes?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: There is some strange divinity within her,
Is there not Valerio?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am not read so far yet as divinity,
Mine is but humane learning.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Speak again,
And at thy lips the quires shall hang to learn
New tunes, and the dull spheres but coldly imitate,
I am transformed with my excess of rapture,
Frown, frown Ardelia I shall forget
I am mortal else, and when thou hast thrown down
Thy servant, with one smile exalt again
His heart to heaven, and with a kiss breath in me
Another soul fit for thy love, but all
My language is too could, and we waste time,
Lead on, there's something of more ceremony
Expects our presence, Italy is barren
Of what we wish to entertain Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: May all the pleasures thought can reach attend you.

div.head: Actus secundus.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Be counselled yet without being too ambitious
To buy a dear repentance.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Now we are.
Arrived at court, shame to our resolution,
I prithee don't tempt me to such cowardice,
Horatio I must see her, she'll not blast us,
She was lovely when our eyes saluted last,
And at my farewell many innocent tears
Witnessed her sorrow, clear as April weeps
Into the bosom of the spring, not see
Ardelia?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You have travelled since, and she
Wanting no beauty, was not over willing
To languish in your absence, how I pity thee,
But that I would not too much vex your folly,
Dost think there's faith in any woman's eyes,
She wept at parting, a strong obligation
When they can thread their tears, and make a chain
Of water, let me wear one of their bracelets;
I will convince thy madness in six words,
Admit she said she loved you, and to your thinking
Vowed it, for you say you were contracted
All this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not this; although
You had been married, and i'th sheets together,
And chaffered earnest for a boy, 'tis nothing
It binds not.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not with a thousand witnesses.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How not bind her?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nor any woman living, that's possessed
with a wand'ring spirit, clap her in a dungeon,
Pile three castles on her, yet she shall
Break prison when she has but the least mind to't;
She le work through a steel-mine, to meet a friend
That she likes better, with more ease throw up
A quarry of marble, than a mole shall dust,
They work with spirits, man, and can do wonders,
Especially a handsome woman, from whose false
And sly temptations, all my wits defend me.
There were some dealing with an elvish female,
That had but a course face, or say but half a one,
Enigmatic eyes, with no more sight than could
Distinguish well, man from a horse, or bear,
To keep her from mistake in procreation,
A nose of many fashions, and as many
Waterworks in 'em, lips of honest hide,
And made to last, teeth of a Moors complexion,
A chin, without all controversy, good
To go a fishing with, a witch's beard on't,
With twenty other commendations, such a thing
Were no mischief, and a man might trust
Her with no scruple in his conscience.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This is plain madness.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You may call it so,
But I'll be bound to travel further with
This nightmare, than the finest flesh and blood
You court, and call your mistress, why the devil
With all his art, and malice will ne'er cuckold me,
And I should leave her in hell, and go a journey,
I should be sure at my return to find her
Safe, and untouched, sound of her wind, and limbs;
A fair, and handsome woman would not scape so:
You have my opinion now, and 'twere less evil
To practise it, you mind not my instructions.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: These lectures have l read toth' city
With the same success, that gentlemen might live honest,
And men have luck to father their own children,
But 'twill not be, you are resolved to try it?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Am I engaged thus far to fall back now?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Remember where you are yet.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I am i'th court.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Where you expect to compliment with the Dukes —

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What do you think? the Duke's married,
They say although he love Ardelia,
And without question, in these parts may want
No intelligence of your purpose, and your person,
And there's no doubt, but if he find you quail-catching,
He has power enough to cool your blood, and hers,
Should she remember what has passed between you,
In that respect be cautioned, do not work
A double ruin, to soothe one vain humour;
Eyes will beget an appetite of more nearness,
And how that may succeed, 'tis better fear, than prove.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I prithee fright me not with shadows.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You are then for her substance — I'll not leave you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I'll see her did the Duke proclaim it death.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I had rather see the cow, with her five legs,
And all the monsters in the market, then
Be troubled with the spectacle, but on,
Stay, yet will you but see her? will her face content you,
Afar off, without multiplying twinkles,
Ridiculous sighs, or crossed arms pinioned thus,
As the kinght-templers legs are, wholly buried,
Like tailors, no djected looks, as y'ad
Your father alive again to send you out
To sea, with pension to maintain you in biscuit,
Poor John, and half a livery, which should be
Part of your governor, to read moral virtue
And lenten lectures to you, or if she frown
As much as say my friend, I am not for you,
The Duke's the better gentleman, and shall pay for't
Will you return then with a handsome patience,
And wisely love where no man else will rival you,
A witch or some old woman,

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I prithee leave
Thy frenzy, thou shalt witness I'll be temperate.
Who's this? Signior Valerio.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Bentivolio, welcome to
Pavie, and the court.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My friend, sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You both divide me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Then I am no stranger,
In confidence of that friendship we both sealed
In travel.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What affairs brought you to Pavie?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Being at large, I had curiosity
To observe what might improve my knowledge here
With some taste of your court.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And I am happy
I have some power to serve your wish, nor could you
Arrive to see it shine with more delight,
It is composed of revels, now all air,
Let me present you to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I shall be honoured to kiss his hand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Shalt see his mistress,
The fair Ardelia, the Duke's no saint,
I may tell thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Pray sir, with your favour,
Cannot the court furnish a gentleman,
And need be, with an ugly face or two,
Such as would turn your stomach, would content
My fancy best.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What means your friend?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: A humour he plays withal.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: He would not play with such a woman, would he?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, and if the place be not
Too barren to afford me one ill-favoured
Enough.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ne'er fear it, they are common here
As crows, and something of a hue by moonshine
Promise to keep your wits, and I'll present you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I have a lease sir, of my brains, and dare
encounter with an army out of Lapland.

div.stage: Enter the Duke, Ardelia, Fiametta, Leontio, Strozzi, Ascanio, Silvio, ladies.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How likes Ardelia this?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: If it affect
Your highness ear, duty hath so composed
My will to obedience, I must praise the music,
And wish no other object to that sense,
Unless you please to express more harmony
By some commands from your own voice, that will
Challenge my more religious attention.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What charm is in her language? cease all other
(But discord to her accents) what a sweet,
And winning soul she has, is it not pity
She should be less than Duchess, far above
Euphemia in beauty, and rare softness
Of nature, I could wonder, gaze for ever;
But I expose my passion too much
To censure, yet who dares dispute our will?
Leontio look upon Ardelia,
And tell me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What sir?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Canst see nothing there?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I see a spacious field of beauty sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis poor, and short of her perfection,
Bear her this other jewel, I will have her
Shine like a volume of bright constellations,
Till all the world turn her idolater:
When did Euphemia look thus?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Never sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Be judge thyself Leontio, if my Duchess
Loved me, could she deny her Dionisio
This happiness, but she has a stubborn soul.
She has, and shall repent it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sir, remember
she is a Princess.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You were best remember her,
Perhaps she'll take it kindly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sir, I hope
You have more assurance of my faith to you
Then to interpret —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Nothing, come, all's well,
Name her no more, howe'er she has displeased
Us, you can violate no duty still
To love her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ay sir?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This infects delight,
Let's dance my sweet Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The Duke's jealous
Or I'm betrayed.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Leontio, Silvio, Strozzi,
The ladies blush for you, they have breathed too much.

div.stage: While the dance is enter Valerio, Bentivolio, Horatio.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, here are gentlemen desire the grace
To kiss your highness' hand.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ardelia supply our Duchess absence,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is the Duke's desire by his example, you extend your
Fair hand to a pair of strangers, ambitions of the
Honour.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Bentivolio?
'Tis he, how my heart trembles as my frame
Would fall to pieces, do you know that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let him attend me in my lodgings
It will be worth your friendship to conduct him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Your countenance changes, I observed
Your eyes upon that stranger.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: He revewes
The memory of a brother, I loved dear,
that died at sea: I never saw two so like.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: For representing one so near Ardelia,
Receive another welcome, and what favours
Your thoughts can study from our court, possess 'em.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You oblige my humblest services — how now, how dost like this?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Why scurvily, you flatter
Yourself into destruction, I see
The arrow will pierce thy heart, decline it yet.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Still franticly opposing.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I ha' done
Be mad, I'll give my brain to somewhat else,
Sir, I would see a phisnomy, though it look
As big as the four winds, I ha' courtship for it,
And woe not he blown off with an hurricano,
Yet trust me I'll be honest.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I believe you.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Only to please my eye.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What think you of
That devil's landscape, you observed not her,
Notwithstanding her complexion, she is a lady
Useful at court, to set of other faces,
Especially the Duke's mistress, whom for that,
And some thing else his grace has recommended
To be her companion, will she serve turn?
Did you ever see a more excellent walleye

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I marry, sir.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Nay let me prepare you,
Madam d'ye observe that gentleman,
The ●●aring stranger, he has business to you,
And you will bid it welcome.

sp.speaker: Fi.
sp.l: Does he know me?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: He enquired for you
By all descriptions — and I guess he may
Be worth your favour.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Mine?

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: If ever man
Were an idolater, he is yours, I'll bring him
To your lodgings madam, if you please.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: You'll honour me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Again to our revels, there's no life without being active,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not now? you shall have opportunity,
And I have commission to inform you something,

div.l: Away here's like to be a storm.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: What's she?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Euphemia.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Your Duchess, sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How dares she interrupt us?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A guard about my heart, I am undone else.
Each look, and motion in her grief present
Such a commanding sweetness, if I observe
With the same eyes I shall betray myself.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: I come not sir, with rudeness of my language,
Or person to offend your mirth, although
The nature of my sorrow is so wild
It may infect weak minds, and such as have not
Some proof in their own bosoms, but to make
One, and my last suit, which when you have heard
It may appear so reasonable, and proportioned
To what your thoughts allow me, that you will
Find easily a consent to make it fortunate,
And me in the prevailing.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Do not move.
Ardelia, I am full protection here.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: There's something sir in my request to make her happy too,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: I dare not hear the Duchess,
Her looks wound me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Speak your promising wishes.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Although I know not for what guilt in me
Of more than my obedience, and some less
Beauty then dwells upon Ardelia's cheek,
You have exiled me from your love, and bosom,
And worse than one condemned by force of laws,
For sin against your bed have sentenced me
To wander with disgrace, carved in my brow
The fable of a Duchess, and your anger;
My desires are you would have so much charity
though you have made me an outlaw by your doom,
Not to compel me after all my shames
To be a murderer.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Treason, our guard.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: You shall not trouble sir your fears I bring
The least black thought against your person, heaven
Avert so foul à sin, the danger all
Doth threaten me, and my life, which I thus
Most humbly beg may not be forced through blood
By my own hands urged by your heavy wrongs
To such a desperate mutiny, which you may
Prevent by your revenge of law upon me.
To which, and your displeasure I would yield
My life your welcome sacrifice, I'll praise
Your mercy for my death, and bless the stroke
Divides my sad soul from me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This your project?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Did you hear the Duchess suit?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: No, but I'll beg
It may be granted, do not sir deny
Your Duchess her desires so just, and reasonable;

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How's this? she'll pray to be rid on her,
Audacious woman

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Let me rise with horror.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ardelia knows not what Euphemia asked.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: She'll appear cunning.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: I am confident
She hath propounded nothing ill becoming.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nothing, a very trifle, wearied with
Her injuries she only begs the Duke
Would be so kind to order with as much
Conveniency as he please, her head to be
Chopped of, that all, and you were charitable
To join so modestly in the advancement
Of her desires.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Defend it heaven,
Madam your pardon, I imagined not
You aimed such cruelty upon yourself.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Proud, and dissembling woman, at such impudence
I take my spirit to me, and no more
Will put my breath to the expense of prayer
To be short-lived, I will desire to live
To see heaven drop down justice, with such loud,
And public noise of my revenge on thee,
And thy adulterate arts, as the world naming
But once Ardelia, shall be palsy-struck.
I feel a new, and fiery soul within me,
Apt to disperse my rage, which fear and my
Religion would ha' stifled. O my fate!

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: She raves, to prison with her, we are not safe
While she enjoys the freedom of our air:
Stay (My good genius) she carries yet
The title of our Duchess; 'tis our pleasure
Leontio, she be your prisoner,
But see her narrowly confined, till we
Determine what shall follow, in what we
Limit, you not make your own reason guide,
But on your life secure her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your commands
In all things I obey, most blessed occasion!

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Fool, thou dost entertain what must undo thee,
And make you both ripe for eternal absence;
Hug Juno in the clouds, and court her smiles,
Though she consent not, 'tis enough you'll stand
Suspected, and exposed to equal danger.
You sha'not lose your air to plead for death,
Thus we'll secure Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: I hear,
And with all cheerfulness resign my will
To imprisonment, or death; forgive the wildness,
And fury of my language, I repent
My wish upon Ardelia, may she live
To do so too, and you to be possessed
Of all joys, earth and heaven can bless your heart with
May danger never in a dream affright you,
And if you think I live too long, 'tis possible,
Before you send death to conclude my sufferings,
Some thoughts of you may wither my poor heart,
and make your path smooth, to what most you joy in
Be not a tyrant when I'm dead, upon
My fame, although you wish me not alive,
Yet say I was Euphemia, let that stick
Upon my tomb, if you will grace my shade
With so much cost, in that name is supplied
Enough to tell the world for whom I died.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We hear too much, away with her.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I have given a treasure to your bosom sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You sha'not friend repent it, and this act
Of so much confidence, new binds my faith to you;
Contracted to Ardelia? I may chance make use of this.
Your pilgrimage ends here —

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Do you know
What you have done?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I have told him what
Concerned Ardelia, and myself; thou wod'st
Suspect, and chide my credulous nature, come,
I'll trust him with my life.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That's done already,
He has a secret, much good do him wilt,
Should ha' burned a passage through my heart, and left
It ashes, ere they'd wandered from me thus,
And if you never did before, pray now
He may be honest to you, 'tis too late
To find compunction for it, pray, and heartily
He may be dumb.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Signior Bentivolio?
So, so, that's over, now I'll conduct you
To your precious saint, unless your blood turn
Coward.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ob, never fear it, sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But would you did
First tell me and discharge me of some wonder,
You have an humour of the newest fashion
I ere yet saw, and how the court may follow't
I know not, how long have you been possessed sir?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Possessed? what devil do you mean?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: With these ill-favoured, deformed women, you're bewitched sure?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Thou dost not know the fiends I have conversed with.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: I have no ambition to be acquainted
With any goblins, further than their knowledge
Might make me understand the ground of your
Enchantment.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: O a world, legions, legions.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Of handsome women.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They the cause of this?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Their false, and perjured natures, I ne'er met with
One handsome face that made a conscience of me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And d'ye think to find
More faith in those that look all o'er like devils?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: 'Tis possible they may have souls, who knows?
Howe'er in my revenge, I'll love, and dote on 'em,
And justify thy are the sex's glory.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have enough.
They are returned, this way sir, to your fairy.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My dearest Bentivolio, why dost stand
At so much gaze, and distance, as thou wod'st
Teach love unkindness, can these out ward forms
Disguise me from thy knowledge, let's salute,
My lips retain their softness, and unless
thy love be changed, our breath may meet, and we
Convey the hearty meaning of our souls,
As we once did.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You're very brave Ardelia,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: But have no pride without you, these are no
Glories compared to what I wear within,
To see thee safe, whom my fears gave up lost,
And after so much absence, do I live
To embrace my Bentivolio?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You would have me
Believe i am welcome hither, fair Ardelia,
Pardon, I know not yet what other name
To call you by, and if I wrong your titles,
Be gentle to my ignorance; this hand
You gave me once, when no ambition frighted
The troth we vowed, our chaste simplicity
Durst kiss without a shame, or fear to be
Divorced by greatness, tell me, sweet Ardelia,
When I did court thy virgin faith, and paid
An innocent tribute to thy most chaste lip,
When we had spent the day with our discourse,
And night came rudely in to part us, what
Were then thy usual dreams? how many visions
Were let into thy sleep, thou shouldst be great,
Torn from my bosom, to enrich thyself,
And a Duke's arms? and that a time should come,
When I, the promisd master of this wealth,
Should thus present myself a beggar to thee,
And count thy smiles a charity?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: What means
My Bentivolio by this passionate language?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I do confess I was compelled to be
An exile from thee, in obedience to
My father, who would trust me to the seas,
Or any land, ere leave me to this shipwreck,
For so his anger sinned against thy beauty,
Whilst the idol gold graced not thy fairer temple,
Yet when we plighted hearts, Ardelia,
I tied with mine an everlasting contract,
and did expect at my return to have found
Thine spotless.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: 'Tis the same.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The same to me?
What makes you here then? do not, do not flatter
Thy guilt so much. Is not this Pavia's court?
Ardelia's court indeed, for she rules here,
The lady Paramount whilst the Duke himself
Bows like a subject!

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Be not, sir too credulous,
And with too apprehensive thoughts do injury
To that which you should cherish, the Duke is —

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You'll say none of your subject,
He is a prince,
Prince of your province, writs Ardelia his,
'Tis ravished all from me, and I am become
A stranger to my own, nay stand, and see
My treasure rifled, all my wealth ta'en from me,
And dare not question the injurious power
That revels in my glory, but canst think
I will be cold for ever, that all seeds
Of man lie dead within me, and my soul
Sunk in my phlegm, will never rise to form
Some just revenge? think there are then no furies.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: You come to threaten not to love, and having
Already by long absence made a fault,
To quit yourself would lay a stain on me,
'Tis not well done.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The Duke.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The Duke?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: 'Tis possible
He may not fear your anger.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I'll squat then
Behind this hedge, this garden hath quiet shades,
I hope you'll not betray me.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: This the form
Of your revenge,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My fair Ardelia
Excuse me if I press upon thy private
Walks, love gives a boldness to mean spirits,
But in a prince's breast: 'tis much more active,
And fears no imputation, what doth fright
Thy countenance? I hope Ardelia
My presence brings no horror.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Sir, much comfort,
Whether it were my fancy or a truth
I know not.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: You have no satires
Within this ground, do any haunt this garden?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Satyrs?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: As I have read 'em charactered,
So one appeared, or I imagined so,
And as you entered hid himself, they are
Half men — —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Half beasts.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: With goat's horns in their forehead,
The thought on't troubles me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The effect only of melancholy thoughts,
No such things are
In nature, yet I'll search, and — strange apprehension.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Twas more than shape, sure it did talk to me,
And threaten me for your sake.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How? for mine?
I'll have the trees, and arbours all torn up,
Devils lurk here? the earth shall not secure 'em,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: He said he loved me, and accused my heart
Of perjury, as we had been contracted.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: More strange! my guard!

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Stay sir, before you go
Let me beseech your justice in defence
Of my much injured honour, as you are
A prince, I do beseech you speak all truth,
For let him be the devil, I'll not have
my innocence abused, I know not from
What fame, or fond opinion voiced of me,
By some that had more thought to serve your will
Then virtue, I was made believe you loved me,
Which though my force resisted by some practises,
You gained my person hither, and in court
Command my stay.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Entreat, my best Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You may sir, smooth your cause, but I can fetch
A witness from my bosom to convince
The truth I urge, yet let me not be lost
To gratitude, my soul bids me acknowledge
Never was subject to a prince more bound
For free, and beauteous graces, than Ardelia
To your highness, and with many lives to waste
In service for them, I were still in debt to you.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis in thy power to satisfy for all,
And leave me ten times more obliged to thee.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let me for this time beg on answer from you,
Although I am not ignorant, what price
Your wild blood would exact, speak in the ear
Of silent heaven, have you obtained so much
As one stoop to your wanton avarice,
One bend to please your inflamed appetite.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Not any yet, the more unkind Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Speak clearly by the honour of a prince.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: By better hopes I swear, and by thyself.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You do me sir, but justice, I will study
To pay my humblest duty, and I'll tell
When next I see the satire — —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: To discharge those fears, I'll presently destroy,
This garden, and not leave shelter,
For a bird.

sp.speaker: Ar
sp.l: Your pardon,
To what would my imagination lead me?
I see all was but melancholy, here was nothing.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Fruits of a troubled fancy, come be pleasant,
And tell me when you will redeem your cruelty,
it may incline you somewhat to remember
By what soft ways I have pursued your love,
How nobly I would serve you.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Love, your grace
Knows, never was compelled.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: But love should find
Compassion to the wound it makes, I bleed,
And court thy gentle pity to my sufferings,
All princes are not of so calm a temper,
Think of it my Ardelia, and reward
The modest expectations of a heart,
That in thy absence withers, but I'll have thee
To chide thy cruel thoughts, and till our lips
Salute again, flatter myself with hope
Thy nature will be wise, and kind to love,
Where 'tis so fairly courted.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Is he gone?
With what acknowledgement of my fault Ardelia
Shall I beseech thy pardon, I am lost
In wonder of thy innocence; 'twere just
I should suspect the truth of my own bosom,
Thou hast too rich a goodness.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now you flatter,
I knew no way o'th sudden to convince you,
But by the Duke's confession, I am yet
Preserved my Bentivolio, but with what
Danger of being lost to thee, and honour
I shall remain here, may concern our jealousy,

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Together with the knowledge of thy virtue
Like balsam poured into my ear, I took
A poison from the Duke, I find he loves thee
With a black purpose, and within his language
Was something worth our fear indeed, it will
Require our study, and much art, Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let's retire into my chamber, and mature
Some course for both our safeties.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I attend you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I won't stay three minutes, I'll but step aside for distillation. I leave you the pleasure of your eyes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Well, go thy ways.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Do you not mock me sir, shall I believe
A gentleman of your neat, and elegant making,
Can stoop to such a creature as I am.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Will you have me swear?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: By no means.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Then I won't,
But I will give it thee under my hand,
Read that.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Something to show I hate all handsome women.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Is't a song?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: It may be, with a voice, and tune put to't,
I'll read it.

div.stage: Enter Ualerio, with Aurelia, and Macrina veiled.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: L am come again sir, and choose, rather than
To afflict you with expectation,
To bring my company along, you may
Salute 'em if you please.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: They are not welcome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will you believe me now?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: If we may trust our eyes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ladies you must excuse me, I affect
No vulgar beauties, give me a complexion
Cannot be matched again in twenty kingdoms,
You have eyes, and nose, and lips, and other parts
Proportioned.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sure the gentleman's distracted.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: No, I am recovered, I thank my stars,
To know, and heartily abhor such faces,
What come they hither for? d'ye know 'em madam?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: I had no purpose they should be my guests
At this time, they're court ladies, I confess,
Signior Valerio this was your plot.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: My pure intention, madam, to do you
Service, I knew they were not for his palate,
These will inflame his appetite to you,
And set you off, mere foils to you do they
Look as they were ambitious to be
Compared with you.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Noble sir, although
I have not beauty like these ladies.

sp.speaker: Ho
sp.l: How? you ha' not beauty, take heed do not show
Yourself unthankful to wise nature, do not
They ha' not wealth enough in all their bodies
To purchase such a nose.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ha, ha, good madam kick shaw,
That laugh to show how many teeth you have.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Be not uncivil sir.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Why does that fairy grin then?
I'll justify there is more worth, and beauty,
Considered wisely, and as it preserves
Man in his wits, and sense, than can be read
I'th volume of their flattering generations.
Good madam look a squint, a little more,
So, keep but that cast with your eyes, and tell me
Whose sight is best, hers that can see at once
More several ways then there are points i'th compass,
Or theirs that looks but pointblank.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: A new way
To commend the eyes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You think your forehead pleases.
Whose top with frizzled, and curled hair beset,
Appears like a white cliff, with reeds upon't;
Your nose, which like an isthmus parts two seas.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Seas? you mean eyes again.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: What of their nose?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Will be in danger, with continual beating
Of waves, to wash the paint off, and in time
may fall, and put you to the charge of building
A silver bridge for praises to pass over.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: We'll bar your commendations.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: It sha'not need,
I do not melt my wits to verse upon
Such subject, here's an instrument to smell with,
Tough as an elephant's trunk, and will hold water.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It has a comely length, and is well studded
With gems of price, the goldsmith would bid money for't.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Is he not mad?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I can assure you no,
And by this token I would rather be
Condemned to'th galleys, then be once in love
With either of your phisnomies.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You may put your whole faith upon't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: D'ye believe him?
Madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Methinks this is the prettiest mirth,
You have a mighty wit, could you be angry
I love you for't.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: His humour takes me infinitely.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: It does, and you do love me for't?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Most strangely.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I would you did, and heartily.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Love me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: So well, I could be happy in thy wife.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Could fate make me so miserable if I did not
In less than a seven-night break thy heart, shouldst
Cuck old me at my own peril.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This lady has
A mighty estate.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: 'Tis all the fault she has,
Would she had none, had she no house, nor clothes,
Nor means to feed, yet I would sooner marry,
Observe, this naked savage, then embrace
The fairest woman of the earth, with power
To make me lord of Italy, I should always
enjoy my health.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her very face would keep
Your body soluble.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: No fears compel me
To be a prisoner to my dining-room,
I might hawk, hunt, and travel to both Indies.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Give any doctor leave to give her physic.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Or change of air.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Save much in your own diet,
Which else would call for ambergris, and roots,
And stirring cullises.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You might allow her
To visit masks and plays.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: And the bordelloes,
I think she would be honest.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And that's more
Than any Christian conscience dare assure
By oath on your behalf to be short ladies,
Howe'er you may interpret it my humour,
Mine's a Platonic love, give me the soul,
I care not what course flesh, and blood enshrine it;
Preserve your beauties, this will fear no blasting:
I beg you call me servant.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Did you hear him?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: You must acknowledge than I am your mistress.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I'll wear your periwig for my plume, and boast
More honour in't, than to be minion
To all the ladies of the court, dear mistress
If you can love a man, jeer 'em a little.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Fair ladies will you in, and taste a banquet,
Be not discountenanced that this gentleman
Is merry with your beauties the spring lasts
Not all the year, when nature that commands
Our regiment will say, faces about,
We may be in fashion, no controlling destiny.
Passion, who curled your hair? here wanteth powder,
Who is your mercer, madam? I would know
What your cheek stands you in a week in taffeta?
Your face at distance shows like spotted ermine.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Or like a dish of white-broth strewed with currants.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Right servant, that was a more proper simily,
Discretion should ha' put more ceruse here,
Your fucus was ill made, d'ye you not lie
In a mask all night, madam.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Thou dost in a vizard
I will be sworn how the rude Gipsy triumphs

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Enough, they now begin to swell, and sweat,
Let's leave 'em.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What a Hecate was this?
Will you not be revenged?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes, if we known
By what convenient stratagem.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I have it,
There is another creature of my acquaintance,
If you have faith more monstrous than this beldame,
I will possess her with this gentleman's humour,
And screw her up to be this witch's rival, what think you of that?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Will it not make her mad?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I would go a pilgrimage to see't, 'twill be
A mirth beyond the bears.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Lose no time then.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll fit him with a female fury, such
As the devil with a pitchfork will not touch.
Come madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Have comfort madam,
I prophecy your sufferings are short-lived.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: You mean I shall die shortly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: We shall find
Less want of all the stars, the aged world
May spare their light, while 'tis possessed of yours,
Which once extinguished, let those golden fires
Quite burn themselves to ashes, in whose heap
Day may be lost, and frighted heaven wear black
Before the general doom, have bolder thoughts,
And bid us all live in your only safety.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Let not your fancy mock the lost Euphemia?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let not the apprehension of your sorrow
Destroy your hope, should the Duke never wake
His senses steeped in his adulterate lethargy
You cannot want protection, nor your will
To be revenged, an arm to punish his
Contempt of so much beauty.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: How my lord?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What Scythian can behold an outrage done
Upon these eyes, and not melt his rough nature
In soft compassion to attend your tears?

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: My lord I know not with what words to thank
Your feeling of my sufferings. I will now
Believe I am not lost to all the world;
You are noble, and I must be confident
These streams flow from your charity.

sp.speaker: Loe.
sp.l: Do not injure
The unvalued wealth of your own honour madam,
Let poor deserts be worth our charity,
All sacrifice of grief for you is justice,
And duty to the altar of your merit,
These drops are pale, and poorly speak my heart,
Which should dissolve into a purple flood,
And drown this little island in your service,
Name some employment that you may believe
With what true soul I honour you, o madam
If you could read the volume of my heart,
You would find such a story of you there.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Of me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis that keeps me alive, I have no use
Of memory or reason, but in both
To exercise devotion to your excellence.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: My lord I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are
More apprehensive if you would but think so,
In vain I still suppressed my dark thoughts madam,
Which in their mutiny to be revealed
Have left a heap of ruins worth your pity.
O do not hide that beauty should repair
what my love to it hath decayed within me,
For I must say I love, although you kill
My ambition with a frown; and with one angry
Lightning, shot from your eye, turn me to ashes.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Good heaven!

sp.speaker: Leo
sp.l: I know what you will urge against me,
You sha'not need to arm your passion,
I will accuse myself, how much I have
Forgotten the distance of one place beneath you,
And wounded my obedience, that I am
False to the Duke, the trust imposed upon me,
And to his favour which have made me shine
A star, on whom the other emulous lights
Look pale, and waste their envies, I confess
I have not in the stock of my desert
Enough to call one bounteous smile upon me,
My whole life is not worth your liberal patience,
Of one, one minute spent in prayer to serve it,
Yet after all wished destiny commands
The poor Leontio to love Euphemia.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: What do I hear? consider sir again.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: I have had contentions with my blood, and forced
Nature retire, and tremble with the guilt
Of her proud thoughts, seeking to make escape
Through some ungentle breach made by our conflict
But no prevailing against love, and fate,
Which both decree, me lost without your mercy.
O bid me live, who but in your acceptance
Shall groan away my breath, and whither till
I turn my own sad monument.

sp.speaker: Fup.
sp.l: No more,
Is't possible new miseries should o'ertake
Euphemia? O my lord I with what offence
Have I deserved, after my weight of sorrow,
Your wounds upon my honour? call again
Your noble thoughts, and let me not reply
To your unjust desires, if I must answer them,
Take my most fixed resolve, ere I consent
To wrong diovisio.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: May: be blasted,
Though with contempt he look upon me now,
His blood may clear, and he return to challenge
Euphemia's pretty, our vow was made
For life my lord, and heaven shall sooner fall,
And mixing with the elements make new chaos,
Than all man's violence, and wrath upon me
Betray one thought to break it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Lose not all
Your peace at once, vouchsafe I may wait on you.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: I know my prison.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let me hope in this,
My pardon sealed Pallante?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: My good lord.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your humble creature madam, though the Duke
Confine your person, think upon your prisoner.
Our vow was made for life, 'twas so how swift
An apprehension love has? but he's Duke;
Conscience be waking, I shall launch into
A sea of blood else, steer my desperate soul
Diviner goodness.
How I start at shadows?
Love take me to thy charms, and prosper me
Pallante thou art faithful.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: To you my lord,
May I be ever else condemned to an hospital.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And dar'st assist to make me happy.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Yes,
Though with the hazard of my throat-cutting,
I hope sir, you suspect not, name an action
Though it look ne'er so ghastly, see how much
I'll tremble at it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: In thy ear.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Once more
Tough service i'th beginning, may I not think on't?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: And ask myself a question ere I answer.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You may.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: At first dash kill the Duke, no less
To begin withal, how now Leontio?
Was there no other life but this, for saving
Of mine so often? he has trusted me,
To whom shall I turn traitor? pray my lord,
Are you in earnest? would you have this done?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ask one, whom tyranny hath chained to'th oar
For ever forfeited to slavery.
Whether he would not file off his own bondage,
And in the blood of him that owns the galley
Swim to his freedom.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Do you apprehend it
So necessary? why I'll do my poor endeavour,
Nay, 'tis but modest, if't concern your lordship
In that degree, I'll do't, you will have some
Convenient care of me, when 'tis dispatched,
He scorned my valiant buff, I thought upon't,
You are the next in blood, when Dionisio
Visits the worms.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou giv'st me a new life,
With the same care I'll cherish thee Pallante.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: And you do not,
It is not the first conscience hath been cast
Away in a great man's service, cheer your heart sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It is not mine Pallante, I have lost
The use and sway, 'tis to another's grown,
And I have but the ruins of my own,

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter Horatio, and Fiametta, dancing a coranto.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: So, so, now let's relieve our lungs a while,
They'll tire, I ne'er met with such a dancing devil,
My destinies take me to your charge, 'twill give
Us breath, if the musicians exercise
Their voice upon the song I made, come sit.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: You shall command me servant, now, the song.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The lady Aurelia, madam, and Macrina
Are come again to visit you.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: I am not
In tune for their discourse, say, I am busy.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: By no means, she has a plot upon me.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Then I'll meet 'em.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Do not fear but I am fortified;
Here were a purchase now, and pension with
A mistress, many a proper man's profession,
Nature meant she should pay for't, and maintain
A man in fiddlers, fools, and running-horses,
Here were no fear of any lords return
From tennis, no suspicion at home,
To force her to a politic pilgrimage
To try the virtue of some well, no kinsmen,
With looks to keep the flesh in a we, no children
To cry, and fright the house their mothers smothered.
They are here.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I wonder at Valerio's stay.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: He won't be long absent, never fear madam.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ladies, I have no power to bid you welcome,
Or if I had you would scarce thank me for't,
You know my mind already.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: See he's come,
And his bear with him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Signior,
You see what care I have to provide for you,
There is not such another dapple-mare i'th dukedom,
Unless this face content you, you may stay
Till the Cretan lady go to bull again,
Or Afrique have more choice of monsters for you.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I am ravished.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: How's that servant ha? A rival.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Pray what's her name?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her name is Scolopendra.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Scolopendra? I have read of her, what kin is she
To the serpent with a hundred legs?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know not
But she is cousin-german to the salamander
She was a cookmaid once, so enured to fire,
And tough, the flames of hell will hardly scorch her.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: An admirable dragon, can she speak?
Will she not spit fire if I should salute her?
I'll venture.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He has preservative
Against the odour of her lungs.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: He had need
Of fortification for his eyes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Not all
The spices in Arabia are like
Her breath.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O sir, believe't, right Styx, most pure Avernus.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: Sir, i did never see a gentleman
Whom I did wish more heartily my husband.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To beget scorpions on her.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Thank thee my precious Scolopendra, but
I have a kind of fear thou wot be unconstant,
Shall no man get thee from me; here's a face
Is worth my jealousy, and who looks upon't,
But with my eyes will be as mad as I am.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: The needles not more constant to the North.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But for all that, the needles wavering
I would be certain.

sp.speaker: Fia
sp.l: They conspired to wrong me,
I fear he's taken with her more deformity,
Will you forsake me servant?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Humstand off,
And give my eyes play further yet, your shadows
Are yet too near — my judgement is confounded,
Consider one thing with another, they are both
Such matchless toads, I know not which to choose:
You have an excellent eye, but there's a pearl
In hers, no goldsmith knows the value on't.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Observe the colours in my eye.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You're right madam,
As many, and more bright than those i'th rainbow
Delightful as the parrot's plume, but then
Her forehead —

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: So like a promontory or —

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: A field of honeysuckles, and poppy-flowers
Embroidered with daisies, and embossed
With yellow-warts which like to molehills swell,

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Where many emmets hunt, and sport themselves
I'th sun, till to her hair a quick set hedge
I'th evening they retire.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But twixt her eyes
You may discern a forest, some higher timber
Is so well grown, that fashioned on the top
With scissors and cut pointed like a pyramid,
The world will take her for an unicorn.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Good beetle-brows.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: Sir, you must be my champion.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Examine but this nose.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: I have a toter.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Which placed with symmetry is like a fountain
I'th middle of her face — distilling rheum,
And at two spouts doth water all her garden.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But here's one soft as 'twere composed of wax.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: A nose of wax.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: It will melt presently.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Not stubborn, but submits to any shape,
She'll put upon't round, flat when she is pleased
She can extend, and hang it with such art
Over her mouth, that when she gapes into
The sun, and shows her teeth, you will imagine
You see a perfect dial in her chaps,
To tell you what o'clock 'tis, than her lips.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I see not so much red there, as will make
A dominical letter, look upon these cheeks —

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: I never painted, sir.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Here's red enough.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Which hideously disposed, and mixed with black,
The ground of her complexion will mortify
The most unnatural concupiscence,
While her cheeks represent in curious landscape,
Gomorrah, and her sister Sodom burning.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: That comparison was home.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But she has a breath,
A more preservative than mithridate

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: But with one kiss she will preserve you from
The infection, and with stronger force repel
The poison of the air.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: I thank you sir,
I have a strong breath 'Indeed

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: When she is moved
She'll kill you with her phlegm, fourscore point blank,
The innocent part of it will stain a marble,
Let me alone to commend thee.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: She carries not destruction like my tongue
Employed upon thy enemies Horatio.
The bells rung backwards, or the mandrake's cry,
Wolves howling at the moon, the screech-owl's dirge,
The hyen's voice, the groans of parting souls,
added to these, what is in nature killing,
To the ear is not more fatal than my tongue
When it is bent on mischief, shall I blast
This witch to begin withal?

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: Blast me?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Belch backwards,
And then she's a dead woman.

sp.speaker: Sco.
sp.l: I'll tear your snakes.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Mine Hecate.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Well said Scolopendra.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: They wonot skirmish.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: The devils will run at tilt.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Madam suffer this?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Compare with me?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Sa, sa, sa, now sound a point of war.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Madam the Duke.

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: His grace has spoilt the duel,
And we must sound retreat.

div.stage: All go forth but fiam. Enter Duke, Silvio, Ascanio, Valerio returns, and falls in with the rest.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We trusted to your art about Ardelia,
She makes no haste to our delight.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: And please
Your highness I have had a strange hand with her,
And I must tell you she was pretty coming
Until the stranger came.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What stranger.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Signior Bentivolio
Nay I know nothing by 'em, but he has
A most prevailing tongue upon a gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My fears! have I advanced him to supplant me?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Bentivolio so gracious with the Duke?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: He's courted next Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: 'Tis for her
We may imagine the Duke graces him.

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: O there is no such instrument, believe it
As a court-lady to advance a gentleman,
Or any masculine business, they are sticklers

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more. Signior Bentivolio.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Where's Horatio.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: He was afraid you might kill one another,
And so he's gone to hang himself.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Better all
Thy generation were executed, but I must to my charge

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Your highness' pours
Such infinite graces on me I shall want
Life to express my pious duties, though
Time should assure me ages.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thank Ardelia,
Or if you would express your gratitude
To me.
Employ your wit, and tongue, to gain
That lady to our close embrace, you have
A powerful language, be it your first service
We do not place this confidence on all.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You mean Ardelia.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: That fair one, Strozzi.

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: Well signior Bentivolio, my quondam
Friend, and fellow traveller, you owe
To me a part of your court exaltation,
And lest you should forget, as few great men
Are guilty of good memories, I mean
To pay myself.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I must not appear troubled.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I congratulate your favour with the Duke,
And think it, not the least of my own happiness.
That I was a poor instrument —

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You honoured me,
And shall command my services: how sped
My friend Horatio?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: He gave me thanks
I ha' fitted him, you missed excellent sport.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I shall have time to inquire, and thank you for
The story, you know how to excuse me friend,
If some engagements force me hence?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Why so.
He has the trick already, full of business,
Court agitations, he is yet scarce warm,
How will he use us when his pride boils over?
A nod will be a grace, while we stand bare,
And thank him for the rufling of his countenance,
And discomposing his court face, that's bound
Upon some state affairs, 'tis very well.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Give him access, thou hast showed diligence,
And trust me to reward it.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: 'Tis my duty sir.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I have some intelligence will be worth your hearing too.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Speak signior Valerio.

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: Do you know the gentleman
Whom you have graced so lately.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Signior Bentivolio.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: That's his name, but do you know his nature?
Or his business in these parts.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Prithee instruct me.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: You do but warm a serpent in your bosom,
In short he loves your mistress.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ho's?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: More is contracted,
And they both practise cunning, I ha' searched
His heart — your ear —

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The Duke seems moved,

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.l: Most strangely!

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Expect a while.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Humbly your grace's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: Your highness shall not waste a passion,
I am of counsel with his thoughts, and will
Present him ripe to your just anger, trust me
To manage things a while.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Honest Valerio.
Val. keep your face smooth, lest he interpret sir,
I ha' betrayed him, ere his head be ready
For the execution, it were necessary
I should examine her pulse too.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ardelia's?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll creep into her soul to bring you all
The best intelligence.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Precious Valerio!
Endear me by this service, thou hast my heart.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My duty shall preserve it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Strozzi.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: This is the gentleman, an't please
Your highness, can discover most strange things.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: To your private ear.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ardelia? my best health,
Dear as my soul, I cannot be long absent.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: So, how shall I begin now?
Madam, I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: To me
Noble Valerio, be confident
For your own worth, if any power of mine
Can serve your wish, you shall not find me slow
To exercise it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis in your power.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Presume 'tis finished then.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In your free power,
Without the Duke, or other to confirm it.
You're flesh, and blood.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No other than I say, nor wish it other,
A woman is a partner in the frailty
Of humane nature, and knows how to excuse
The errors of our blood, and yet you shall
Have cause to give me thanks, when you consider
My sense, and your own state, what d'ye think
of me?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For what you please to call it,
My persons not contemptible, though I be
No Duke, I can behave myself to please
Where I am accepted.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: What's your purpose signior?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You cannot sure be ignorant of my meaning,
There's not a girl of seven years old, but will
Expound it readily, here we suck this language
And our milk together, I could have used
More circumstance, have praised you into folly,
And when I had put out both your eyes with metaphors,
Lead you to my desires, and to your pillow:
But 'twas about, I could have said I loved you,
Looked sad, and squeezed my eyes, have sighed perhaps,
And sworn myself quite over breath, that I
Thought you a saint, and my heart suffered more
Than the ten persecutions; hang't, time's precious,
I take the nearest way, which your discretion
Will like me for, yet I can love you too,
And would for thy embrace forget as
Goodness, and tempt as many mischiefs as,
Another man, I hope you understand me.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: I am lost, and see a black conspiracy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You shall see me naked. I ha' no conspiracies,
Carry no private engines more than nature
Armed me withal, be wise and do not tremble.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How dare you be thus insolent? though my person
Move you to no regard, you shall find one
Will teach you manners.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You would mean the Duke now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Has that name no more reverence owing to it?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Yes, I desire no better judge, he'll hear
Us both, and equally determine all;
Let's to his highness straight.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What means this rudeness?

sp.speaker: Ua.
sp.l: You are the Duke's game-royal, or else should
Be the mistress of his thoughts, whose nod does make
us tremble, and in time may be the Duchess,
Unless your sweet heart Bentivolio
Snap you before him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: What fine nets you walk in,
You are no, juggler, there has passed no contract
Betwixt you, and the gallant, no? and while,
The honest easy Duke, whose spirit raise not,
Dotes on that face, humbled beneath a subject,
You have no private meetings, change no kisses,
Nor hot careers, alas he's but a stranger
Whom you respect but for the bare resemblance
Of a dead brother, there's no flame in you
But what lights you to charity; I waste breath,
The Duke is yet that tame thing, you ha' left him,
His soul in a dream, let not your folly,
And peevish opposition to receive
Me to your arms, wake him into a tempest,
The lightning cannot move more nimbly, than
His rage to both your deaths, your Ganymede
Will find the Duke's revenge in his hot blood,
When his heart weeping the last drop shall have
No pity wait upon 'em, that durst feed
The rival to a prince, though common men
For want of power, and courage to revenge
Neglect their shame, wild princes that know all things,
Beneath their feet but heaven, obey no fate,
And but to be revenged will hazard that.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Not so madam,
You shall lead destiny in cords of silk,
And it shall follow tame, and to your pleasure,
The Duke knows nothing yet, you shall seal up
My lip to eternal silence of your love,
If I may but enjoy you, you shall rule
With the same sway his bosom, and possess
Your wealth in Bentivolio too, I'm but
A friend or rather servant, that shall be
Proud of your smile, and now, and then admitted
to kiss you when the curtains drawn, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Who placed me on this precipice? sir, hear me,
'Tis vain to ask how you derived the knowledge
Of what I thought concealed, you are a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: That does appear by my desires.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Have yet some mercy
On a distressed maid.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Maid? thank you for that, I would you were
Indeed, virginity is wiser than
