Men take it for, and therefore we distinguish,
There is one virginity in the wedge, or bullion
As we may say, and this we call lunor maidenhead,
And there's another in the coin, the gold
Is not less gold for the impression,
Your maidenhead is currant in this sense.
And in this maiden-sense you may give milk.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: By all the goodness that I wish were in you,
Not Bentivolio, whom you think I most
Affect, hath more of me then virgin knowledge,
Nor hath the Duke with all his flatteries
Wronged my first state, although I must confess
He every day expects my fall from virtue,
Do not you more sir, than the devil could,
Taking advantage of my wretched fortune,
Betray me to a shame will kill us both,
In fame, and soul.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: In fame? who shall reveal it?
And tother may repent.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sir, can you kill me?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: No, no I sha'not hurt thee, women are not killed
That way, I mean to skirmish, come you may
Save all with little study, and less hazard.
What is the toy we talk of? either resolve
Or the Duke knows all, and perhaps more.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stay sir.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Yes, yes madam I can stay, and be till
Tomorrow for the sport, I am not so hot
But I can bathe, and cool myself.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Can you
be just hereafter if to buy my own,
And my friend's safety at so dear a value.

sp.speaker: Va
sp.l: I'll cut my tongue out e'er reveal my tongue,
All my concupiscence, and the cause, I will
Submit to thy own carving; fear not me,
I hate a blab worse than an honest woman,
Why so? this wisdom is becoming thee,
No blubbering, kiss me, and be confident,
A pretty rogue, tomorrow shall we meet?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Woe is me tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: No, thou shalt laugh tomorrow,
I'll come to thy own lodgings, that's but reason,
Farewell, another kiss, be comforted,
And safe, the Duke knows nothing, all shall live,
And we'll be very loving, mighty merry.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I must do something to prevent this devil.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Why so, this bargain was well made, and timely.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I have no peace within me, till I hear
How bold Pallanto thrives, o love upon
What desperate actions dost thou engage us?
With scorn of opposition, like a fire
Which till it turn all that his flame can meet with
Into itself, expires not; fair Euphemia!
Bright in thy sorrows, on whom every tear
Sits like a wealthy diamond, and inherits
A starry-lustre from the eye that shed it,
The Duke must die — have I betrayed myself.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Hold, my lord you know me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: For Valerio.
But must hand-back that secret, 'twas not meant
So early for thy knowledge, from thy bosom
I'll tear or drown it in thy blood, passed search
Of dangerous intelligence.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Hold my lord,
You shall not need,
think my lord I know
The world, and how to keep a secret too,
Though treason be contained in't, I am not
So holy as you take me, my good lord
For some ends of my own, I wish the Duke
In another world as heartily as your lordship,
And will assist to his conveyance thither,
Though I be quartered for't, that's fair, and friendly,
You love Euphemia, why 'tis not amiss,
I love Ardelia, (I trust you my lord)
You for the wife, I for the concubine,
How could the Duke being in heaven, hurt me now?
You are his kinsman, were his favourite.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: O sir, there is a gentleman my rival,
One Bentivolio got a round above you
In favour —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He shall die.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: No, let him live
A little while, to kill his highness first,
And take your own time then to turn the ladder.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou talkest a mystery.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: It shall be clear,
Be advised, and second me my honoured friend,
You, and my lord be more familiar.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sir, I shall serve you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Make me happy
My lord, by your commands.

sp.speaker: Ua. Ardelia
sp.l: Your mistress is in health — nay be not stirred.
I have done you a courtesy by acquainting
My lord how things stand, and introth he pities you,
We have had a counsel merely concerned you,
And the poor gentlewoman, whom the Duke has not
Yet lured to fist.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I know not how to thank you.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: He's next heir to'th dukedom, and has power
When his grace dies — imagine, a sweet soul
May I perish in my hopes, if his eyes did not
Melt when I told thy story, and how much.
The innocent lady suffered.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I am bound
Much to his goodness.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sir I would do more
Than pity your just cause.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Nay we ha' cast it,
And so much above blood, and state, has virtue
Impression in his heart, he can forget,
And think the Duke a dead man.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Excellent lord!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am ashamed, and trust me have applied
What my poor learning could affect, to cool
His riotous blood, but he's incorrigible,
And now more desperately bent then ever.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: To violate her?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I blush to say't, nor will
Your person be long safe.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Well interposed.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: He shines on me with bounteous smiles.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: They are dangerous,
And but engage you to a greater ruin.
You stand discovered.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: That's my wonder sir,
D'ye think your friend Horatio has not wronged you
In's drink perhaps — some men are such sponges,
A child may squeeze their soul out.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You fright my senses.
I do now suspect, the Duke's command towards Ardelia confirms it.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Wisdom must prevent
I know thou hast a daring spirit, we
Are friends, 'tis clearly our opinion
You should by steel or poison — you conceive me
For your own safety, and your wives, I call her so
Whose life, and honour lies a bleeding, 'tis
Nothing to me, my lord I told you, is
next heir, and cannot but in conscience pardon you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Twere pity thou shouldst suffer more.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: But dare
Your lordship mean this.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Be confirmed.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Your counsels
Have met a spirit, apt in my revenge
To fly upon the world, I hope I shall
Be construed in his death, to have done your lordship
No great discourtesy, being next heir,

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: 'Tis to be understood.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The dukedom made
Mine by his death, is nothing to the crown
Of fair Ardelia's love, in whose free bosom
My pardon, and best wishes shall soon plant thee
Passed the divorce of tyrants.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I am new
Created, and build my hopes upon your honour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: They are secured dost think he's firm, and daring.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: If he kill not the Duke — I'll cut his throat,
He sha'not scape howe'er, if I have brains
I must have all his venison to myself,
I'll spare nor haunch nor humbles, o my lord
Be confident if he meet the Duke, and time
Though it cost him a day's journey, he'll go through him
'Tis his own cause; he was wound up discreetly,
You do not by this time repent your secret.
I can be wicked upon good occasion,
The devil sha'not part us now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Be constant,
And meet the truest friend,

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Meet at a wench
Till then your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: My fate smiles
Conscience steers not ambition by what's good,
Who looks at crowns or lust, must smile at blood.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: He will no longer be put off with ceremony,
You must consent this night to his embrace,
Or take what follows madam.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am lost,
And every minutes filled with new despairs,
It is in your power to persuade him yet.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: I have said too much already.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Say I am not
In health, poor refuge!

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Not in health, the Duke
Shall give you physic — there be ladies no
Dispraise to your beauty, would be sick a purpose
To have the Duke their doctor.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What can cure
My sick fate? o my heart, poor Bentivolio,
On what high going waves do we two fail,
Without a star or pilot to direct
Our reeling bark? Valerio too expects
A black reward for silence, he is here,
Already? do not leave me Fiametta,
I charge thee by thy duty to his highness.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Let me pay a duty
To her white hand, whom the Duke only honours,
You look not with a cheerful countenance madam.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am not well my lord.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I am excellent at
restoring health, send of Tisiphone
I would not have her picture i'th room
When we are at generation.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: She's commanded
To stay here.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: How? commanded? Madam I have
Commission to impart some private meanings
From his highness to this lady.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: And I have
Order, this my lady have no such conference,
But I must be a witness.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: You will not
Contest I hope, and dispute my authority,
What an officious fury 'tis? how shall I
Be rid on her? Madam you see this ring,
A friend of yours signior Horatio
Desires another meeting by this token.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Where is my noble servant?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: But you must
Express your love in making haste, I knew
Although for mirth I flattered Scolopendra,
That you would carry him, but lose no time.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Lend me thy wings sweet love to fly to him.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Fly to the devil, he wants a companion,
I'll shut the door after your beldamship,
And trust myself with key.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You do not mean
To play the ravisher my lord.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: As if
You meant to put me to't, I have your promise
And where consents meet in the act of love,
The pleasures multiply to infinite.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Infinite horror! yet my lord, be a man.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: You shall not doubt that madam, if you will
Apply yourself discreetly, we lose time,
Although I be no Duke, I can present thee
With all the pleasures, appetite can wish for
Within love's empire, when you know me madam ▪
You will repent this tedious ignorance,
and not exchange my person, to clasp with
The greatest prince alive, (Christian or infidel,
Though I commend myself, I ha' those ways
To please a lady.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ways to please the devil?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: You won't be coy now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My lord I know,
At least I hope, howe'er you speak a language
Rather to fright then court a woman's thoughts,
(Not yet acquainted with her own dishonour)
You have some love within your heart.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Canst thou
Suspect it? wilt thou see my heart?
Give me a fortnight's warning, and let me
But all that while possess thy love, and those
Delights I'll prompt thee too, I'll wish to live
No longer, get what surgeon thou wot
To cut me to a skeleton, not love thee?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Then by that love my lord, I must desire you
At this time to defer your expectation,
And leave my chamber.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Quit the chamber madam?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: If not for love of me, for your own safety,
There is danger in your stay, for every minute
I do expect a visit from the Duke.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: This is some trick, you sha'not fright me lady,
I must have that I came for.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Meet it here
Licentious devil, I shall do a benefit
To the world, in thus removing such a traitor,
To man, and woman's honour, you shall carry
No tales to his highness, if thou hast a soul.
Pray, 'tis my charity to let thee live
Two minutes longer.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Madam, Ardelia,
You won't use me thus,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Will you pray sir?

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Alas I have forgotten, I ha' not prayed
This twenty years at least, I am willing madam
to obey, and quit the chamber, pardon me,
My ghost may in revenge else, do you a mischief,
And betray Bentivolio to the Duke,
But if you let me live, I will be dumb,
Madam consider a wild flesh, and blood,
And give me leave to spend my rest of life,
Only in thinking out some fit repentance,
For I will never speak, if you suspect me.
The Duke is come already, I am undone
Mercy, and some concealment.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ardelia
Alone, I heard another voice, with whom
Were you in dialogue, and the door so fast?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It is but your suspicion.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This dissembling
I like not.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: If he know who 'tis, I shall
Inflame his jealousy — dear heart appear
Less troubled, do not throw such busy eyes
About the room, I'll whisper't in thy ear,
The Duke —

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: There, obscured behind the hangings
Upon thy entrance.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Guilt has made him fearful,
O I am lost, and thou art now not worth
My glorious rescue.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Softly, by all goodness
He has not injured me, and if you durst
But trust our private conference, I'll die
Rather than bring thee ruins of my honour.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: If thou beest yet white, my own arm secures thee
From all his lust hereafter.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: O
sp.stage: He wounds Valerio behind the hangings.
sp.l: I am murdered.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What have you done?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Nothing but killed the Duke,
You shall with me?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: No matter where.
So we escape the infection of this air.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: I am caught in my own toils, by the same engine
I raised to the Duke's death, I fall myself,
The mystery of fate, I am rewarded,
And that which was the rank part of my life,
My blood, is met withal, and 'tis my wonder
My veins should run so clear a red, wherein
So much black sin was wont to bathe itself,
I would look up, and beg with my best strength
Of voice, and heart forgiveness, but heaven's just,
Thus death pays treason, and blood quencheth lust.

div.stage: Enter Leontio, melancholy. Some cry treason within.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Although I love, and wish the act of treason
The noise yet comes to near me.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: O my lord!
The Duke is killed.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The Duke? by what black murderer?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: That gives the state another wound, we cannot
Suspect who was the traitor, to revenge it,
But whosoever was guilty of this parricide,
Is still within the court, the deeds so fresh
He cannot be far off.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Shut up the gates,
And plant a strong guard round about the palace,
Let none go forth in pain of death, the devil
Sha'not obscure him here with his black wings,
Though he rob hell to cover us with darkness,
We'll find him under twenty fogs, and drag him
To his just torment.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You're his pious successor.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis done, and my ambition's satisfied
Contain my heart, but to which bold assassinate
Pallante or Bentivolio must I owe
This bloody service.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: I ha' don't my lord.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Softly, thou art my brave, and glorious villain.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: There have been better titles sir, bestowed
On men of my desert, the killing of
My lawful prince, hath been esteemed an act
Above the reward of villain, though I know
I am one, and a monstrous villain too,
I would not be called so.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou shalt divide
Titles with me, dost think I'll not reward it?
Thou art sad.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: I am a little melancholy
After my work.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Dost thourepent thy service?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Were he alive, I'd kill him again for you.
'Tis not his death that haunts my conscience,
But the condition, and state he died in,
That troubles me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What state, or what condition?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: When I had taught him to believe he was not
Long lived, and that your lordship had by me.
Sent him a writ of ease, for I'll make short.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Didst thou discover me?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Why not? I was
To take an order he should ne'er reveal it,
Upon the mention of your name my lord.
He fetched a sigh, I thought would have prevented
My execution on his heart, as if
That were a greater wound than death upon him,
But I, whose resolute soul was deaf to his prayer,
Bathed in as many tears, as would have wrought
A marble to compassion, bid him choose
The humour he would die in, and collect
Some thoughts to wait upon him to eternity,
and what do you think he made his choice?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: To die an honest man, no wish to part
The world with fair Ardelia in his arms, and give his ghost up in a wanton kiss.
But with a thousand groans, calling upon
Euphemia to forgive him, to whose virtue
His soul was going forth, to meet, and seal
To it, a new, and everlasting marriage,
Nay he had so much charity to forgive
You sir, and me, and would have prayed for us,
But that I sent the message to his bosom
That made him quiet, and so left his highness
Had he died obstinate in his sins, the wanton
Lascivious Duke he lived, I would not blush for't.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why, dost relent for this?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: I find some mutiny
In my conscience, pray my lord tell me
Do not you wish it were undone.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou hast
The tremblings of an infant, it exalts
My thoughts to another heaven, Pallante thou
Must not leave here, but make Leontio, owe
His perfect blessing to thy act, go to
Euphemia, and with thy best art drop
This news into her ear.
Within. Away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What tumults that?

div.stage: Enter Bentivolio, and Ardelia with officers

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: My lord we have found the traitor
He does confess he killed the Duke.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He killed the Duke? 'tis Bentivolio.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I did my lord, you sha'not trouble much
Examination, with this hand I sacrificed
Ferneze, and you ought to call my act
Pious, and thank me for removing such
A tyrant, whose perfidious breath had heaven
Been longer patient would have blasted Parma.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And in the confidence of this service done,
You present yourself to be rewarded.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I meant not to have troubled you for that
had not their force compelled us back.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Come nearer.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I wonder at this noise of the Duke's death,
Valerio's tragedy is all that we
Are guilty of, which yet I have concealed
From Bentivolio.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Had you no aid
To this great execution, did you do't alone?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Alone, and 'tis my glory that
No hand can boast his fatal wound but mine,
And if you dare be just my lord.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Be confident,
There is some mystery in this Pallante
Both could not kill the Duke, he does accuse,
Himself.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: I am all wonder my good lord.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are sure 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Now you dishonour me,
D'ye know blood royal, when you see't, you may
Believe that crimson evidence, I hope
Your lordship will remember.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Fear it not,
But for a time you must be prisoner
To satisfy a little form upon
My life, no danger shall approach thee, trust
My honour, though I frown, and call thee traitor
I will study thy preserving next my own,
Is not this strange Pallante that he'll take
The guilt upon himself, if both have killed him
No fear but he's dead, this fool Pallante
Shall quickly by his death secure thy fate.
Put on a cunning face mean time, and narrowly
Observe the full behaviour of the court,
But 'Specially insinuate with the greatest,
And as they talk of me, declare my passion,
And with what horror, I received the death
Of our good Duke, my pious zeal to appease
That blessed spirit with his murderer's blood,
In care to their own heads, they will proclaim
Me Duke, I'll to Euphemia, and by some
Strong art make her my own.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Your grace is prudent.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Away to'th prison with 'em.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let me bear
Him company my lord.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You sha'not doubt it
Good madam mischief, and repent together,
As you are like to bleed, and with full torture,
Howl out your wretched lives for the Duke's murder.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You are deceived my lord, we won't die
For that offence.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You won't, glorious strumpet.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You're a most
Uncivil lord, thy birth had not more innocence
To justify thy mother.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I'll be modest,
And say, this is not honourable.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: So sir,
You will have time to talk at your arraignment,
Away with 'em, now to Euphemia.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Did you not send for me, and by this token?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Follow me not, unless thou wilt swear to imitate
What I shall lead thee too by my example,
For rather than not be rid of thee, at next
Convenient river I will drown myself,
And think I go a martyrdom by water.
Cannot a gentleman be merry w'ee,
But you will make him mad?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: I'll never leave thee,
I will petition to the Duke, and plead
A contract.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Thou'lt be damned then.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: What care I.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: So, I should have a blessing in this fiend,
This child of darkness once removed, I send for thee,
And by a token? I would sooner send
For the hangman, and pay him double fees
To strangle me, what I endured before,
Think 'twas a penance for some mighty sins
I had committed, and be quiet now.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Did you not love me then?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Love thee? consider
What thou hast said, and hang thyself immediately,
I'll sooner dote upon a mare, dost hear me,
A mare with fourscore, and nineteen diseases,
And she the greatest to make up a hundred,
Then harbour one such monstrous thought, thou art
A thing, no cat that comes of a good kind,
Will keep the company, and yet thou lookest
So like a miserable o'ergrown vermin,
Now I think better on't, it is my wonder
Thou'rt not devoured quick, leave me yet.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Not I sir,
I know you love me still, all this is but
To try my constancy.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Art thou so ignorant,
Or impudent, or both? let me entreat thee
But to have something of a beast about thee.
Thy senses in some measure, look but how
I frown upon thee, for thy safety therefore,
If thou hast no desire to save my credit
Abroad, tame thy concupiscence, we draw
All the spectators but to laugh, and wonder at's,
And I shall be the greater prodigy
For talking so long with thee, wilt be ruled,
And trudge from whence thou camest, good honest bruit,
My humours out of breath, and I ha' done,
But all that's ugly in thy face, or what's
Unseen deformity, I am now in earnest,
And therefore do not tempt me.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: My dear signior.
To what?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Why, after all to beat thee, if
Thou leavest me not the sooner.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Are not you
My servant?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But in passion I forget things,
And if my mistress want discretion,
I shall, in my pure zeal to have her wise,
Beat some into her, most abominably
Beat her, and make deformity to swell,
She sha'not get in to her chamber door.
I'll bruise, and make thee up into a ball,
And boys shall kick thee home, dost thou not fear me?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: I'll endure any thing from thee, my love
Shall think no pain a suffering, come, kiss me
But once, and I will die thy patient martyr.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: She would be killed, to have me hang for her,
Was ever such an impudence in woman?
You that are handsome ladies, I do ask
Forgiveness and believe it possible
You may be less vexations to men.
Dost hear? to tell thee truth, for it will out
By some, or other, you must here discharge
Your dotage, for it is but two hours since
I was married.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Married? to whom?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Toth' tother
Wild bear that courted me, to Scolopendra,
She met i'th nick, and we clapped up.
And you know 'tis not conscience to abuse
Our honest wedlock.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: I shall run mad.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Would thou wouldst run into the sea, and see
If I would go a fishing for thee.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Furies,
Rise in my brain, and help me to revenge.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I am afraid she'll beat me now.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: False man,
I have not breath enough to rail, and curse
Thy apostasy, how couldst thou use me thus?
But seek some sudden way to be divorced,
Or one shall die.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Would thou wert buried quick.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: But are
You married, tell me sweet Horatio,
And must I wear a willow garland for thee?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Wear a halter.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: It is not possible, thou canst be so
Unkind to me.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You may believe it madam.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Yet I must love thee till I die, and you
May keep me alive, with now, and then some favour,
It wants no precedent, we may kiss I hope,
And thus walk arm in arm, would deny
Thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Do not vanish me good madam.
The people hoot already, none to rescue me.
Is not this Bentivolio, under guard,
And his fair mistress pinioned? how now friend,
Wither are you bound with such a convoy.
To prison, they are traitors.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Traitors.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Do not believe 'em.
They have killed the Duke.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: How's that?
Do you know him sir?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Dear madam are you prisoner too.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Take me along,
Better be hanged then haunted with that goblin.
Another of the conspiracy disarmed him.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Let me but speak a word to this old damsel.
She's of the plot too.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: I? I defy him,
I know him not.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I hope you won't leave me in distress
Love, mistress ladybird.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: I defy all traitors
Away with 'em, the Duke killed! out upon 'em,
That fellow always had a hanging countenance
Bless me, defend me.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: 'Tis well treason will
Make her forsake me yet.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Dost know on what
Danger thou dost engage thyself?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Although
I die for company 'tis worth it gentlemen
you know not how you have relieved me madam,
I did expect you'd bring him into mischief,
I am perfect in your sex now, come to prison.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You may repent your malice sir.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And you
May be a saint, away with us, come friend,
Women have made me weary of the world,
And hanging is a help, we might ha' lived
If you had ta'en my counsel, nay I'll share w'ed
I ha' not lost all my good fellowship.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: My sorrows, I forgive you all, this blessing
Has overpaid my heart, and though it crack
With weight of this so unexpected happiness,
I shall die more than satisfied.

sp.speaker: Duke and Euphemia.
sp.l: Thou art too merciful, and my repentance
Is yet too feeble, and too short a wonder,
Sure thou dost flatter me, if not heaven suffered,
My fall with holy cunning to let thee
Shine the world's great example of forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: But wherefore does your grace come hither thus
Disguised, being yourself, and mine again, what needs
This cloud upon your person, truth did never
Shame the professor.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Though I live to thee,
The world do think me dead Euphemia,
Leonato whom I loved, and trusted most,
Designed my everlasting farewell from thee,
But he that should have been my executioner,
Without disordering this poor heap of nature,
Gave me another life, and growth to virtue,
Pallante, blessed good man

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Leonate's creature,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: That honest soldier after by his counsel,
I put this shape on, while to my false kinsman
He gives relation of my death, this key
He lent for my access to thy sad chamber,
I hope he is returned.
'Tis Leonato.
My heart o'th sudden trembles with the fear
Of a near danger, I am unarmed too,
For our defence — madam you are not wise,
And merit not this providence to dote
Upon a shadow, your dead husband, when
Leonato lives, with more ambition to
Succeed him in your love, than this fair dukedom.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What fellows this that pleads my cause, 'tis some
Pallante has appointed to prepare her,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: With pardon, you deserve him not, and were
I Leonato — my good lord.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Spare your
Dull rhetoric sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: That I could snatch
His sword, I dare not call for help, or leave 'em
She may be lost within a pair of minutes,
My heart, my brain!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Madam you said your vow
Was made for life, Ferneze's death hath cancelled
That obligation, and in midst of tears
Fate smiles upon you, if you dare look up,
And meet it with a will to be made happy
He courts you now, has power to kill all sorrow,
From these fair eyes, be just to your kind fortune,
And dress your face with your first beauty, madam,
It may become the change, why weep you still.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: I weep for you my lord.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: For me.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Because
You cannot for yourself, pray tell me sir,
Is the Duke dead in earnest, you have not
A mourning face, but great heirs seldom die
With sudden grief, or weeping for their father,
Or kinsmen's funeral, I pray how died he?
Although he were not kind to take his leave,
I would pay my obsequy of tears upon,
his hearse, and weep a prayer to his cold dust.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That may be time enough.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: How I desire
To kiss his lip again, o show me yet
Where's the pale ruins of my dead lord? stay
He shall have half my soul, where's a soft,
And silent breath I will convey to warm,
And quicken his stiff bosom.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Madam, what's
All this to my reward?

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Reward for what.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: My love which for your sake, and let me tell you
Not without some encouragement from you,
To give your heart more freedom to meet ruin,
Hath sent the Duke to heaven.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Thou art a murderer,
Treason?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Treason.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Who was that.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Some echo
Within the chamber, nothing else my lord.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is not the Duke's ghost hovering hereabout,
It has a clamour like his voice, ha, but
I can take order for your silence, use
That tongue again, with the least accent to
Affright the air, and I'll dismiss thy soul,
To wait upon thy husbands angry shade.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Horror? what can preserve us but a miracle?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yet I'll not so much favour you, 'tis death
Perhaps you have ambition too.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: One word
My gracious lord, it has been my trade to deal
With women, with your pardon you do practise
Too tame a courtship for her nature, use
The opportunity, and force her, to your
Pleasures, away with sword, and buckle with her,
Leave me to keep the door, I ha' been used to to't
She'll thank you when 'tis done, lose no time in talk.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ha? do thy office.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Would your lordship know me?
You shall — what think you of this officer?
False to thy blood; thy honour, and thy prince,
You're caught my precious kinsman, and I live
With my own hand to be revenged upon thee,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ha then thorough her, I will receive my mends,
I did suspect that voice, had not my confidence
Of thy most certain death betrayed me thus,
I would have made sure work, some fate direct
His sword thorough both our hearts.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No treason, treason.

div.stage: Enter Pallante, Strozzi, Silvio, Ascanio, with a guard, they wound Leonato.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: So let me employ the short breath that remains
To tell you I engaged Pallante, to
The Duke's death with a full hope to satisfy
Lust, and ambition, but he juggled with me,
And so has Bentivolio, though he be
With his Ardelia in prison, for
Acknowledging himself your murderer,
To which Valerio, and myself inflamed him.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Valerio traitor too.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sir he is slain,
His wounded body found in Ardelia's chamber.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ardelia!
This dark mischief shall be cleared
Strozzi, command Bentivolo,
And Ardelia be instantly brought hither?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Most ingrateful Leonato.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know I am not worth your charity,
And yet my lord your cruelty upon
Euphemia, and some licence I took from
The example of your wanton blood, was ground
Of these misfortunes, 't seems you're reconciled,
Be worth her love hereafter, thou wert just,
Pallante, be still faithful to thy prince,
I beg your general pardon.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Heaven is a great way of, and I shall be
Ten thousand years in travel, yet 'twere happy
If I may find a lodging there at last,
Though my poor soul get thither upon crutches
It cannot stay, farewell, again forgive me.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: He is dead.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: I pity him.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: The prisoners wait.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Admit 'em.
Was your life so great a burden
That you upon the rumour of our murder,
Would take the act upon you, though you had
Promised to be the traitor, or did you
Envy another man should own the glory,
And title of our bloody executioner.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ay, but confessed the guilt I then believed.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This is a mystery.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I can best clear it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Tis my wonder how?
Valerio was slain.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: That I must answer,
Although my sword then promised to another
Revenge, yet in the wound he met a justice,
I now repent not.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: What's that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I am one madam that do court my friend here,
So well that though he be in fair election
To lose his head, or to be strangled —
Had rather take such as I find with him,
Then live to be tormented with a woman.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: What woman.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Any woman, without difference,
I have heard your grace has a good fame, and though
It does become your subjects to believe it,
I was not born here madam, and I've had
Such ill luck with your sex, it does not bind
my faith, 'tis possible there may be good
Both fair, and honest women, but they were never
Under my acquaintance, no no yet ill-favour,
In whom I only looked to find a soul,
But boast my labour. This is all truth madam:

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: His humour makes me smile.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Enough, not only
Our pardon for Valerio's death, I give
Thee back Ardelia, she was my mistress
But I return her pure as thy own wishes.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This grace is mighty sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We'll see you married,
And what our person, and Euphemia's
Can add to grace you.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You've already blessed us,
And heaven shower joys upon you.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The next thing is to honour thee Pallante,
Thou savest my life, and didst now marry me,
Thy faith is not rewarded.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: 'Was my duty.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What, is all well again? and is she honest.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Most innocent.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Then she's too good for thee,
Come the truth is, and now I'll speak my conscience
If there be few good women in the world,
The fault rise first from one of our own sex,
By flattery in falsehood to deceive 'em,
And so the punishment does but descend
To us in justice.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: That's some charity.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come my Euphemia, this second knot
Shall be as firm as destiny, nor shall
Whatever was to our chaste vow a shame,
In my lives after story have a name.

lg.l: Gentlemen, and ladies,
If I have transgressed in any language
〈◊〉 handsome faces, I hope you will forgive
Me, and imagine, I have but played the part, which
Was most against my genius, of any that ever I
Acted in my life, to speak truth,
Who is so simple to dote upon witches, and hel-cats.
Venus deliver us, the poet stands listening behind the arras
To hear what will become on's play, under the
Rose if you will seem to like it I'll put
A trick upon him.
For though he hear when you applaud, I'll say
Your hands did seal my pardon, not the play.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
